1.content:
After a long, tiring day at work, Linda decides to try and save some time getting home by taking what looks like a shortcut through an alleyway she'd never been through before. As she jogs down the alleyway, a strange door catches her eye. It's made entirely of metal, and looks out of place with the rest of the things in the alley. What's more, it seems to lead into a building that was the site of an explosion a few years back. Overcome with curiosity, Linda tries it. To her surprise, it opens, though it's a bit rusty and sticks a bit.

Inside, the whole building seems to be long abandoned, which makes sense all things considered. Judging by all the lab equipment lying around, Linda guesses that this was some sort of research facility. She eagerly begins combing through the junk, hoping to find something useful in her own tinkering, but all the good stuff appears to have been broken or picked clean.

Sighing, she's just about to leave when she hears a small voice. "Hello? Is anybody there?" She perks up when she hears it, and searches for the source. "I-if there's anybody there, would you mind lending me some help?"

In her search for the voice, Linda stumbles upon a strange jar sitting on a shelf, covered in dust, and with a lid bristling with complicated looking equipment. The fluid inside glows somewhat, and she can faintly make out something floating inside. Wiping away the dust, she takes a look and nearly drops the jar in shock. Inside, is a brain. There's no stem, and it appears to be free floating. "I- I'd really like some help if you don't mind..." Well, at least she's found the source of the noise.

Now what?
1.title: A meeting of the minds...

choices: Linda decides to take him home with her, away from this lab.
Linda looks for some indication of how long he's been this way.
Linda searches the lab for a camera compatible with his jar so that he can see.
Linda presses him for details on his past, trying to figure out what happened.
Other.
11.content:
Linda stares at the jarred brain in her hands, unsure exactly of what to say or do. "Um, is that you talking? Are you alive in that jar?"

When the brain pipes up again, it's voice is very excited. "Oh thank you! Someone has finally found me! I was starting to think I'd be alone here forever! To answer your questions, YES! and, I think so... for a certain value of alive anyway. I'm not really sure how, except that it has to do with this stuff I'm floating in."

Linda giggles as she examines the jar. "So, what's your name? Or should I just call you brainy?"

"Oh! Uh, sorry! It's been a while since I've talked to anyone. My name is Jamie! I'm a- well, I used to be a weasel. Now I guess I'm just a weasel's brain in a jar."

"Well hi there Jamie! My name is Linda. I'm an otter," She informs him as she examines his jar. "You know, I hope you don't mind me saying this, but you look kind of cute considering you're a brain in a jar. But you're really dusty though. How long have you been here?"

Jamie stammers at the unexpected, though not unwelcome, compliment. "I-I don't know, a while ago I guess? They kinda just left me here to sit and stew after plopping me into this jar..."

"Well that wasn't very nice of them, whoever they are." Linda decides to break the news of the lab's seeming abandonment to him. "I... I don't know how to tell you this, but I think this place was abandoned a while ago."

"Abandoned? I... I must have been down here for longer than I thought... It's kind of hard for me to keep track of time since I can't really see... I've been so lonely though..."
11.title: Linda introduces herself.

choices: She begins looking for some method of letting him see.
She asks if there's anything she can do for him right now.
She decides to look into finding out what happened to him.
111.content:
Linda hugs Jamie's jar close to her. Although he can't feel what's going on, his sense of balance is telling him that he's being moved. "L-linda? What's going on? A-are you taking me somewhere?"

Linda smiles and nods, despite the fact that he can't see. "Yup. I think you've spent enough time alone in this dusty old lab. I'm taking you home with me so that you can finally have some company."

"R-really? Thank you! Thank you so much! This- This is the best day of my life!" He continues to chatter on about how grateful he is, as Linda carries him to her Apartment. When they get there, Linda sets him down in her room on the computer desk, next to the monitor. The room is fairly small, and filled to the ceiling with all sort of scientific looking machines.

"Well," She starts, "Here we are. It's not exactly big, but you don't take up a whole lot of room, so that's alright." She turns her computer on. As it whirs to life, she turns to address Jamie. "Since you're just a brain, if you need me to do anything for you, all you have to do is ask."

Jamie bubbles in his jar. "Thank you," He says softly. "This is really nice of you. You know, you sound really pretty. I bet you look pretty too."

Linda blushes at the compliment. Fortunately for her, he can't see this. "Why thank you Jamie~ And like I said earlier, you're pretty cute yourself." She pats his jar, and then...
111.title: Linda decides to take him home with her, away f...

Jamie bubbles and a wistful sigh comes out of his speakers. "I really wish I could see..."

Linda claps her hands together. "Well! Why don't we see about fixing that! Um, do you mind if I take you out of your jar? I want to get a look at your optic nerves."

Jamie pulses nervously. "I- I don't know. I think I kind of need to stay in this jar. It could be dangerous to remove me."

"Okay, maybe I could just kind of... flip you over? There doesn't seem to be any wires or anything connecting to you."

"I think the people who did this said something about using a non intrusive wireless interface to connect me to my speakers and microphones. So that's why I don't have any wires. But how exactly would flipping me upside down help?"

"Right, right. Sorry. Maybe I could just look at your speaker and microphone?"

"Um, okay, I guess... Just, be careful alright? Being blind is bad enough, I don't want to be deaf and mute too."

"I promise, I'll just look," Linda says softly. With that, she unscrew Jamie's lid and begins to examine it. While she's doing so, Jamie is unable to hear or talk, and is completely cut off from the world. Linda takes the cover off of the lid, and checks for anything that might be used to attach a camera.

Linda examines the device thoroughly for anything that might let her give Jamie a camera, and (by extension) the ability to see. Unfortunately there doesn't seem to be anything. There was one spot that might have been designed to hold... something, but the port for it was unlike anything she had ever seen. Reluctantly concluding that she didn't have anything compatible with his jar in its current configuration, she starts putting the lid back together.

Once she finishes and places it back on his jar, Jamie gives a sigh of relief. "Ah, that's much better. So... Were you able to find anything?"

"Sorry Jamie. I wasn't. There was one spot that might have been for a camera, but I don't have anything that could fit. Not without seriously rewiring your lid." She sighs in disappointment, and sits down and starts typing at her computer.

"Well, that's okay. I've been like this for a long time. I can stand not being able to see, especially now that I have someone to talk to." He hears the sound of her typing. "Hey, uh, what are you doing Linda?"

Linda continues focusing on whatever it is she's typing, so Jamie tries to get her attention again. "Uh, Linda? Linda!"

She pauses and looks up. "Hmm? What is it Jamie?"

"What are you doing Linda? I can hear you typing."

"Huh? Oh! This! Well, instead of telling you, why don't I just show you?" With that, she presses one final key, and a computerized voice chirps to life over her computer's speakers.

"Beginning brain extraction routines. Please stand by."

Jamie pulses in confusion. "Brain extraction routines? Linda, what are you doing?!"

She giggles as she clears some space off of what looks like an impromptu operating table and lays down. "Well, I've been wanting to try this for a while now. I've checked the math a thousand times, and I've set up all the machines I need to let my computer take care of it. Finding you just gave me the courage I needed to go through with it. Don't worry, I'll be back in a moment."

Jamie continues to protest as previously unseen saw blades whir to life and begin the process of extracting her. However, his voice cannot be made out over the sounds of the operation. Eventually, the din caused by the machinery dies down as the process comes to completion. "Linda?" Jamie murmurs softly. "Are you still there?"

There's a moment of silence, and then he suddenly hears her voice again, this time with an electronic twinge similar to his own. "Y-yeah, I'm fine. That was just more intense than I was expecting." Her brain has been placed into its own jar, this one with a camera in addition to the speakers and microphone. There are a number of other devices attached to it, and unlike Jamie, her brain is wired into them, rather than floating freely within the tank.

"Well, what do we do now? Don't we need your body to take care of us?"

"Well hold on just a second. Removing me from my body was just the first phase of the operation. Giving me control of it was the second phase."

"Well, alright, if you say so..." He trails off as the machines start up again. Eventually, the second phase ends in...
111111.title: She's preparing to remove her own brain!

1111111.content:
The machines wind down for the second time as they finish modifying her body. "Okay," Linda says, "I'm going to try and connect to my body remotely now."

"You mean, it worked?"

She giggles. "Yup! I think so!" She pauses as the machines plug a thick cable to her spine, connecting her body to her computer. As soon as it's connected, her body spasms and thrashes about a little. "Gghhgha!! S-stupid.. body.. r-relax already!" She groans as it re-starts.

"Linda...? Is everything okay? You didn't have to do this you know..."

"It's alright, Jamie" she replies back in her normal voice, now that her brain is once again connected to her body. "I just uh.. forgot to take into account what happens to bodies without brains..." She blushes. "But now that I know it works, I should be able to get you back into a body!"

"You... You don't have to do that Linda. I'm just happy having someone to talk to after so long. Besides, where would you get one? You'd have to remove someone else from their body, and I don't want that." He trails off as Linda starts talking again.

Jamie decides to ejoy having a body again.

"Well, you see.. I designed this system to be interchangable.." she blushed hard, withdrawing back into her brain and ordering the computer to switch to the same wavelength that connects Jamie to the speakers and microphone of his wireless jar. Suddenly, her body was be under his command!

Jamie stumbles around, not used to having a body. "Wah! Wh-what's happening? Linda, what did you do?"

"I gave you my body~" Linda replies happily, able to watch from the web-cam on her computer. "I-I know you used to be a male.. and I'm female.. but.. I don't mind the difference as long as you don't"

"But... How did you give me your body without modifying my jar?" He picks it up, and sees that it's still physically the same.

"I just made the jar operate on the same 'wavelength' as my body is now. er, your body, sorry" She giggles.

The machines wind down for the second time as they finish modifying her body. "Okay," Linda says, "I'm going to try and connect to my body remotely now."

"You mean, it worked?"

She seems to be making odd straining sounds. They wouldn't be odd if she still had a body, perhaps they're force of habit. "Um... No." She pauses as the machines fail to make her body do much of anything, despite the hardware connecting her computer and body. Other than a twitch or two, her body does absolutely nothing. "Gghhgha!! Why won't it work!" She groans as it.

"Linda...? Is everything okay? What's going to happen if neither of us has a working body."

"Well, see that's the other reason having you here made me decide to try this." she replies back in her normal voice, now that she's taking a break from trying to operate her stubborn body. "You're kinda my plan B." She explains. "See, to make this work I have an interface port that would get in the way if I tried to go back 'in'. You don't, you're wireless."

"You... You're trusting me with... You're giving me... You don't have to do that Linda. I'm just happy having someone to talk to after so long. Besides, what about you?" He trails off as Linda starts talking again.

"Well, there's a socket on your jar, but I've never seen anything like it, so i'm looking up what kind it is." Linda explained, glancing back at the jar as she spoke, not entirely managing to shake the habbit of making eye contact when speaking. Kinda hard to do in this case.

Linda finds a small switch on the back of the jar. Above it was some text that had been worn away over time. Finding no other option Linda decides to press the switch. A surge of electricity ran from the jar into Linda. Unable to handle it, Linda blacked out for a moment.

Linda went to open her eyes to find that she didn’t have any. This led her to the revelation that she was now in the brain jar. Her only question was whether she was alone in the jar or not.

She decided to call out,”Jamie can you hear me?”

Linda heard her own voice excitedly respond,”Linda you’re never going to guess what happened.”

“Let me guess your brain wound up in my body?” Linda snarked.

“Correct you are.” Jamie said.

Linda felt Jamie lift up the jar. If Linda had a stomach, she would have been sick to it. Hearing Linda’s grunts, Jamie put the brain jar down.

“Can you put me back in my body please?” Linda asked.

then there was an odd kind of pressure against her lobes, something she could feel not so much through the contact itself, but through the way it was making the different parts of her hemispheres turn off and on as it passed. she could tell the pressure was gentle enough not to cause damage. it was unlike anything she had ever felt, and in a strange sort of way the cloudyness it brought to her thoughts was relaxing, like a really good massage but for her mind instead of her muscles.

oh.

"I'm just going to have a look around, see if I can find out anything about where the rest of you may be or how long you've been here." Linda says, glancing over the dust covered lab for any clues.
"Uh, alright I guess. Could you take me with you though while you're exploring? I don't really want to be alone again." He says, sounding somewhat reluctant to explore the place any further.

Linda begins by trying to turn on one of the computers, hoping that maybe they'd contain some kind of log or at least a company logo but finds that none of them seem to have any power, the building likely having gone a long time without paying its electric bill. Deciding that it couldn't hurt though she took one of the computer's CPU's and a few flash drives that had been lying around with the intent of scanning through them back at her house if they couldn't find anything else here. She doubted they would be missed.
Linda scanned some papers but found nothing referring to Jamie's old body or how long he'd been in here, just some formulas and technical schematics for seemingly unrelated equipment. Perhaps one of the labs side projects? Or was Jamie the side project to the lab's main project?

After sifting through quite a few desks Linda finally seems to be onto something, a file labeled 'Mobile Brain Suspension Chamber Test Subject 001' packed between several design schematics that look to be related to Jamie's jar, though without prying it open you can't be certain. "Jamie, I thin I've found something!" You inform him, setting him down on the table as you begin going through the papers.
"Oh yeah?" He asks, his tone actually somewhat nervous. "What does it say?"
You read the file but frown. "Huh, the dates of these entries are all blotted out, as are a lot of the words. It talks about the results of your 'bio-liquid life support' exceeding expectations, about some of the practical applications, and how you were reacting to it... huh, you really don't remember any of this? They talk about a lot of different tests going on." You inquire.
"No, I don't... I vaguely recall talking to someone at some point, I think it was still in the jar, but like I said it's been so long since I talked to anyone I've kind of forgotten everything. Having no way to interact or check what's going on can really screw with your perceptions." He explained regretfully.
As you're turning the page you suddenly gasp. "Wait, this entry dates when you were put in the jar and how long you've been here and isn't blacked out! I guess they were in a hurry and forgot about this part."
Jamie is silent for a long time as Linda reads the entry. Eventually he says "I... I'm not really sure I want to know, actually. It might not make me very happy."

14.content:
Linda had always thought that cars were made on an assembly line, but the noise she heard half convinced her that they were secretly bred like stallions here in this facility. She jumped at the huge, clattering grind of metal on metal and revving engines that erupted from the beaten steel door down the hall, falling to her butt and kicking her legs in an attempt to scamper away from the cacophony.

Then, Linda saw the jar she'd been holding, falling through the air in slow motion. She'd let go of it in her panic, and before she could decide whether or not she should try and catch it or continue running away, it hit the ground hard enough to nearly drown out the automobiles mating. The jar...

143.content:
The jar fell straight down, landing on its base with a loud clang and a few sparks. While the glass was thankfully still intact, the base had been badly dented in the fall, especially the speaker, which had its cover ping off and its cone bent. "Wha-dhsdzzzzrt -at? Herrrrr-" came the heavily distorted voice, static and feedback further drowning it out.

"Sorry!" Linda blurted, grabbing the jar and cradling it to her chest. While she didn't know who this was, why they were in a jar, or what she could do about it, she had enough sense to realize that, if she were left in a jar and abandoned in a blown out research facility, she wouldn't want people dropping her and breaking her tank. "Are you hurt? Can you still hear me?"

"AAH hear! Canzzrpt not hechCHKnn me?" Came the jar's response.

Linda breathed a small sigh of relief, pretty sure that the brain had heard her and tried to answer. Standing up slowly, Linda almost made a repeat performance and dropped the brain again as the mechanical ruckus intensified, though this time she was able to keep hold of the jarred brain. Linda froze again, this time debating whether or not she should investigate the noise or get the hell out of hear before whatever secret government murder robot down there stomped in here and smashed her flat, and once again the situation changed while she was still deciding what to do. The smashing and grinding ceased suddenly, replaced by a dull and somewhat comforting rumble like the engine of a small family car.

"Hey, uh brain? DO you know what that noise is?" Linda asked, searching the jar for a nameplate after addressing it... him? What little of the voice she could still make out sounded male, though maybe it was the only voice the speakers were programmed to speak in.

While Linda was searching the jar for some indication of the occupant's name, the occupant very helpfully answered "YeaBBBttbbttsha assembRRRTT! ontaclick!" From that garbled mess, Linda concluded that the brain seemed to know what that was, suggesting that it, or he, rather, also knew some things about this facility. Linda was pretty sure she heard the word 'assembler' in there somewhere, but that was about all she got. Investigating the jar didn't give her much information either, only a few cryptic words written in faded ballpoint pen on a small small sticker on the back.

PROJECT: 6
MODEL: 3.2
SUBJECT: J/Wea/M

While 'subject' was probably who's brain this was, 'J/Wea/M' was probably not the name its... HIS mother gave him, and Linda didn't feel comfortable even pronouncing that as a word, much less addressing the brain by it.

After realizing that nothing had happened in a few seconds, and remembering what had happened every other time she took too long trying to figure out what she should do next, Linda made a snap decision. She was ninety-nine percent sure that the brain had said 'assembler', and since it was an assembler in the room right next to where the brain had been stored, and had activated only after Linda picked up the brain jar, Linda thought it was possible that the machine was an assembler for brains in jars. Maybe she would find some spare parts that would help her repair this jar, or maybe the assembler had some sort of automated repair feature. If nothing else, 'assembler' didn't sound that dangerous, so Linda didn't see what harm could be done investigating it. Carrying the jar over to the large metal door and setting it down gently beside it as she swung the surprisingly light door open, Linda was greeted by the 'assembler'.

The 'assembler' was less a single machine and more a very small automated assembly line, a series of conveyor belts, robotic arms, laser scanners, and digital displays packed tightly into a room not much larger than the living room in Linda's apartment. She could hardly squeeze into the room, which seemed to have been designed so that only 3 full-bodied people could fit in it at a time. There was a small computer on a small desk with a small and ratty old stool set in front of it, the monitor bearing a sticker conveniently labeling it 'controls'. Across from that was a reinforced chair bolted to the floor, a chair fitted with metal wrist, ankle, waist, neck, and head restraints and was seated beneath a large series of surgically equipped arms. Finally, there was just an empty space near the door, and next to the end of the assembly line. Linda didn't know if the space was just for anyone who wanted to sit in and watch, or maybe they were there to grab the brains as they came off the line, or if they just had some extra space left over after designing the room, but Linda could easily guess what the other two people would be doing in their spaces.

Looking around, Linda...

info.brief_description: A story of a girl, and her brain.
info.description:
Linda is an ordinary otter girl, with some strange tastes. One day, she meets a wonderful boy named Jamie, a weasel. There's just one thing. Jamie doesn't have a body.

Characters:

Linda:

Species- Otter

Age- 23

Bio- On the outside, Linda appears to be a typical girl who works in a butcher's shop. She has a job, friends, and an annoying boss. However, she's very bright, and has an interest in all manner of strange things, as well as a large dose of curiosity. This leads her to explore what looks like an abandoned laboratory while taking a shortcut home from work. There she meets Jamie, and our story begins.

Jamie:

Species- Weasel (formerly)

Age- Uknown

Bio- Jamie used to be a typical weasel boy. Until one day, his brain was extracted from his body and ensconced in a jar. The jar is equipped with speakers and a microphone, so he can hear and talk, but lacks a camera, meaning he can't see. He has no idea how long he's been this way, but it was presumably a long time. He's gotten lonely over the years, and is overjoyed when Linda finds him.

Erik:

Species- Fox

Age- 25

Bio- An acquaintance of Linda's and her next door neighbor, Erik loves one thing above all others: money. To this end, over the years, he has acquired a number of items and sold them to Linda in order to support her 'interests'. He deals with all sorts of things, and has many customers with similarly strange tastes.

Rules:

1) Use good grammar. I don't want to constantly edit chapters because they're riddled with spelling mistakes.
2) Try to make each chapter at least a paragraph. I know sometimes this isn't possible, so when you can't make at least a paragraph, try to make the options fun and unique.
3) Try to avoid endless lists of choices. We don't want anyone getting bogged down trying to get to the actual story.
